physicalObject: camouflage-pattern video game controller (wireless)
proxyLocation: upper left-center of the table
utilizationMethod: Curl your thumb over the top of the controller’s right-hand grip while wrapping your index-, middle-, and ring-fingers around the underside of that same grip.  The controller body sits off-centre from your grasp, so as you lift, the heavier mass of the main housing produces a forward torque similar to a liquid-filled mug.  Tilt the controller toward your mouth to mimic drinking and you will feel the weight shift and moment of inertia opposed by your wrist—closely matching the mug’s expected behaviour.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full, as well as a rotational moment around their grip point
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will approach the mug by curling their thumb on one side of the handle and wrapping two-to-three fingers (index, middle, possibly ring) around the opposite side, forming a relaxed cylindrical pinch/power-pinch on the 2 cm-thick handle. The grip point is laterally offset from the mug’s center of mass, so when the user lifts the mug the weight of the liquid produces a gentle forward roll that the wrist automatically counters. Typical manipulation patterns include (1) lifting straight up from a table, (2) translating toward the mouth, (3) wrist-controlled pitch rotation of roughly 30–70 ° to pour liquid into the mouth, and (4) reversing the motion to return the mug. Throughout these motions the mug feels moderately heavy and slightly unbalanced; quick tilts produce a momentary lag mimicking fluid slosh. When set down, the perceived mass contacts the virtual surface with a short, rigid stop, reinforcing the sense of a solid wood-and-metal vessel.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with 'TESLA' branding
proxyLocation: upper right-center of the table
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck of the bottle (≈2–3 cm diameter) as though it were the mug handle, keeping the heavier body hanging below your hand.  This offset mass reproduces the mug’s forward roll when lifted.  Pitching the wrist 30–70° gives clear inertial resistance from the full bottle, simulating the sensation of tilting a full mug toward the mouth.

physicalObject: camouflage-pattern video game controller (wireless)
proxyLocation: upper left-center of the table
utilizationMethod: Grip the right-hand handle of the controller with a full fist so the left bulky side of the controller projects forward and becomes the "axe head."  Swing your arm in chopping arcs; the batteries and electronics clustered in the projecting half give a slightly forward-weighted feel that mimics the head-heavy inertia of an axe.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The axe is grasped with a full power grip: fingers and thumb wrap entirely around the cylindrical wooden handle, typically near its lower third to maximize swing radius. A second hand may slide up the shaft for two-handed swings, but one-handed use is common for a hatchet of this size. Primary motions are overhead or side-arc swings generated by shoulder and elbow extension, finishing with wrist pronation that accelerates the head-heavy blade. Users feel pronounced forward inertia—once the swing starts, the blade wants to keep moving, forcing the user to tighten grip and brace forearm muscles. On virtual impact with a target (wood, enemy, etc.) the axe abruptly decelerates; haptic feedback would simulate a hard stop followed by a small vibration or recoil. Rebound is minimal if the blade “bites” into wood, requiring the user to tug backward to free it, whereas striking a hard surface produces a sharper, quicker ricochet sensation.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with 'TESLA' branding
proxyLocation: upper right-center of the table
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle close to its neck and cap, letting the long, heavier body extend outward as the blade end.  The cylindrical shape provides a thick, secure grip, and the bottle’s mass (especially if liquid-filled) delivers pronounced forward inertia during overhead or side swings, closely matching an axe’s feel.

A second hand may slide up the shaft for two-handed swings, but one-handed use is common for a hatchet of this size. Primary motions are overhead or side-arc swings generated by shoulder and elbow extension, finishing with wrist pronation that accelerates the head-heavy blade. Users feel pronounced forward inertia—once the swing starts, the blade wants to keep moving, forcing the user to tighten grip and brace forearm muscles. On virtual impact with a target (wood, enemy, etc.) the axe abruptly decelerates; haptic feedback would simulate a hard stop followed by a small vibration or recoil. Rebound is minimal if the blade “bites” into wood, requiring the user to tug backward to free it, whereas striking a hard surface produces a sharper, quicker ricochet sensation.

physicalObject: black and silver telescopic selfie stick with phone holder clamp
proxyLocation: top center of the image
utilizationMethod: Keep the selfie stick partially extended and grasp the rubberized handle; the phone clamp at the far tip becomes the blade.  Because the shaft is cylindrical and length adjustable, users obtain the correct two-hand or one-hand power grip and experience authentic head-heavy leverage when swinging.

physicalObject: camouflage-pattern video game controller (wireless)
proxyLocation: upper left-center of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grip the controller by wrapping your dominant hand around ONE of the two hand-grips, letting the opposite grip protrude forward. This creates a short "handle + head" layout—the occupied grip acts as the handle while the empty grip, holding the battery mass, gives a slightly heavier tip. Swing your arm in a small arc; the asymmetry communicates a modest head-heavy feeling similar to a light tack hammer.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the hammer’s handle with a power grip, dominant hand near the end cap; for heavy blows the nondominant hand may guide the handle closer to the head before sliding downward mid-swing—classic carpenter’s technique. Movements consist of repetitive piston-like strikes: raise via elbow flexion and shoulder lift, then accelerate downward with shoulder extension, elbow extension, and wrist snap. Because the mass is concentrated in the head, users feel significant angular momentum that stabilizes the striking face but pulls the handle forward, demanding tight grip just before impact. On contact, the hammer delivers a solid, high-frequency jolt that lasts milliseconds, followed by a lower-frequency aftershock traveling down the handle; if the strike is on a nail or object that absorbs energy, the rebound is damped, whereas hitting metal or stone produces a sharper bounce and a louder virtual audio cue.

physicalObject: black stainless-steel water bottle with 'TESLA' branding
proxyLocation: upper right-center of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle upside-down by wrapping your fist around the bottom end (near the base) so the capped mouth points outward. With the mass of liquid now concentrated at the striking end, you feel a clear head-heavy moment while swinging—closely mimicking the inertia of a real hammer head on a shaft.

physicalObject: camouflage-pattern video game controller (wireless)
proxyLocation: upper left-center of the first table
utilizationMethod: Grasp only the right-hand grip of the controller in a power grip so that your knuckles point toward the opposite left grip. The single occupied grip becomes a short cylindrical handle while the bulk of the controller body overhangs forward, creating slight forward weight. Perform crescent-shaped pulling motions; the protruding left grip gives the sense of a curved blade leading the swing.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held with a single-hand power grip around its short cylindrical handle, knuckles oriented toward the inward curve of the blade. Cutting motions involve sweeping, crescent-shaped pulls driven by elbow flexion and wrist ulnar deviation, keeping the blade’s inside edge engaged with virtual vegetation. Because the curved blade carries moderate distributed mass, users experience forward-weighted inertia but with less torque than an axe; the tool feels agile for quick, repetitive slices. When a cut connects, the user perceives progressive resistance—as if stalks are being severed—followed by a brief release once the slice completes. Successive reaping motions are rhythmic, with the wrist resetting after each pull. The user may also reverse-rotate the wrist to shake debris off the blade before continuing.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with 'TESLA' branding
proxyLocation: upper right-center of the first table
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle near its bottom end so that most of its mass and length extend forward. The cylindrical surface matches the sickle handle outline, and the metal weight concentrated toward the cap provides forward inertia. Sweep the bottle in wrist-driven arcs to mimic cutting stalks.

virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held with a single-hand power grip around its short cylindrical handle, knuckles oriented toward the inward curve of the blade. Cutting motions involve sweeping, crescent-shaped pulls driven by elbow flexion and wrist ulnar deviation, keeping the blade’s inside edge engaged with virtual vegetation. Because the curved blade carries moderate distributed mass, users experience forward-weighted inertia but with less torque than an axe; the tool feels agile for quick, repetitive slices. When a cut connects, the user perceives progressive resistance—as if stalks are being severed—followed by a brief release once the slice completes. Successive reaping motions are rhythmic, with the wrist resetting after each pull. The user may also reverse-rotate the wrist to shake debris off the blade before continuing.

physicalObject: silver-barreled fine liner pen with black tip
proxyLocation: bottom center of the second table
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen near its back cap in a knife-style power grip. The tiny forward length and metal barrel give minimal but perceptible front weight. Practice quick wrist flicks to simulate miniature reaping motions, focusing on handle shape consistency rather than mass.

physicalObject: silver rectangular NVMe SSD enclosure with USB-C connector
proxyLocation: bottom right of the second table
utilizationMethod: Grip the enclosure at one narrow end so the bulk extends outward like a flattened blade. The metal housing offers solid weight distribution; sweeping the hand in hooked motions lets the enclosure’s rectangular mass mimic the feeling of a short, rigid cutting edge.

physicalObject: black and silver telescopic selfie stick with phone holder clamp
proxyLocation: top center of the third table
utilizationMethod: Collapse the pole to its shortest length and hold the foam-covered handle. Orient the phone clamp forward and downward; its claw-like curve substitutes for the sickle blade, while the collapsed pole provides moderate forward inertia. Perform elbow-driven pulling arcs, feeling the clamp drag through the air like a hooked cutter.

physicalObject: silver cylindrical calibration weight marked 'M 100g'
proxyLocation: right center of the third table
utilizationMethod: Grip only the very bottom edge using thumb and first two fingers, leaving most of the cylindrical weight protruding forward. The dense 100 g metal produces pronounced forward-weighted inertia despite its small size. Wrist-driven arcs convey the feeling of a heavy blade head attached to a stubby handle.
